results.byline: By Alexandra Alter and Elizabeth A. Harris
results.title: Asked to Delete References to Racism From Her Book, an Author Refused
results.abstract: The case, involving Scholastic, led to an outcry among authors and became an example of how the culture wars behind a surge in book banning in schools has reached publishers.

media.caption: Maggie Tokuda-Hall declined Scholastic’s offer to license her book, “Love in the Library,” on the condition that she edit her author’s note to remove a description of past and present instances of racism.
media.copyright: Marissa Leshnov for The New York Times

results.byline: By Maggie Shipstead and Anthony Cotsifas
results.title: What Survives in the Atacama Desert?
results.abstract: In Chile, a writer takes a road trip through one of the world’s driest places — a landscape that preserves remnants of the dead.

media.caption: The Tara Salt Flat sits at 14,000 feet in the northern Chilean Andes, at the eastern edge of the Atacama Desert. Some 250 miles to the west lies the Pacific Ocean and, in between, a vast, near rainless interior.

results.title: Who Gets In? A Guide to America’s Chaotic Border Rules.
results.abstract: New restrictions on asylum will lead many migrants to be deported — but others will still get into the United States. Here’s what the process will look like.

results.title: 36 Hours in Rotterdam, the Netherlands
results.abstract: With experimental restaurants and avant-garde architecture, the Netherlands’ second-biggest city embodies contemporary urban cool.

media.caption: Depot Boijmans Van Beuningen has landed like a U.F.O. in Museumpark: The huge mirrored building stores more than 150,000 works of the Museum Boijmans Van Beuningen next door, which is closed for renovations.

results.title: Too Many Older Men Are Still Screened for Prostate Cancer
results.abstract: Most have low-risk cancers and rarely benefit from treatment, a new study finds. Actively monitoring the condition is often the best choice.

media.caption: Joe Loree wanted to avoid the aggressive treatment for prostate cancer that he had seen his brother and friend undergo, and opted for a more conservative approach called active surveillance.

results.byline: By Hanya Yanagihara and Kyoko Hamada
results.title: Why Do Cats Hold Such Mythic Power in Japan?
results.abstract: A journey through a country where felines are revered, adored and sometimes seen as actual demons.

media.caption: Ceramic maneki neko, or “welcoming cats,” at Gotokuji, a temple in the Setagaya ward of Tokyo that is dedicated to them. Visitors buy the figurines, scribble wishes on them and leave them on shelves. Usually, real cats are not allowed on the premises; this was a supervised visit.
